choices.text: Higher doses of haloperidol

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with schizophrenia was treated with haloperidol 5 mg once daily at bedtime, which was increased to 7.5 mg daily in the 2nd week and 10 mg daily in the 3rd week. His symptoms improved, but in the 5th week, his family reported that his restlessness had returned, and he kept pacing around in the room, though he was not aggressive. The patient also reported an uncontrollable urge to move around and difficulty in falling asleep. Which of the following drugs would be the best choice for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propranolol

 

The patient's symptoms suggest that he may be experiencing akathisia, a side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol. Akathisia is characterized by restlessness, an uncontrollable urge to move, and difficulty in sitting still.

 

Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is often used to treat akathisia and could be an appropriate choice to address the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Higher doses of haloperidol may exacerbate the patient's restlessness and are not recommended in this case.

 

Option C. Valbenazine is used to treat tardive dyskinesia, a different movement disorder associated with long-term antipsychotic use. It is not indicated for treating akathisia.

 

Option D. Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant used to treat muscle spasms and malignant hyperthermia. It is not used to treat akathisia.

questions.text: A young male patient who is a case of schizophrenia was started on haloperidol 5 mg. On the 3rd day, he came to the hospital accompanied by his father with rolling up both eyes. A complete neurological examination revealed no spasticity or any other abnormalities. Visual acuity was found to be normal. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute dystonia

 

Option A:

 

The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is acute dystonia, which is a type of extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that can occur as a side effect of antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol.

 

Acute dystonia typically presents as involuntary muscle contractions, often involving the muscles of the neck, tongue, or eyes. In this case, the patient's rolling up of both eyes suggests involvement of the muscles controlling eye movements. Acute dystonia usually occurs within the first few days of treatment with an antipsychotic medication and can be a medical emergency if left untreated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Seizures: are unlikely to present with rolling up of both eyes without any other accompanying symptoms such as convulsions or loss of consciousness.

 

Option C. Malingering:  or feigning symptoms for secondary gain, is also unlikely in this case as there is no obvious reason for the patient to fake these symptoms.

 

Option D. Akathisia:  another type of EPS, presents as restlessness, agitation, and inability to sit still, and is unlikely to cause the rolling up of both eyes.

 

  • Anticholinergic drugs like benzhexol is drug of choice for treatment of acute muscular dystonia. Alternative drugs are first generation histamine H1 blockers like promethazine.

choices.text: Administer sodium bicarbonate.
Consider hemodialysis.
Administer fomepizole.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with altered mental status and hypotension. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) shows wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. She has a history of depression and is taking an antidepressant medication. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer Sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option A:

 

The clinical presentation suggests a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, which is known to cause cardiotoxic effects such as wide QRS complexes due to sodium channel blockade. Administering sodium bicarbonate is an effective treatment as it helps to alkalinize the blood, counteracting the sodium channel-blocking effects of TCAs on the heart. This treatment helps to normalize QRS duration and mitigate the risk of arrhythmias, providing an immediate therapeutic benefit in acute TCA toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Consider hemodialysis: While useful in certain poisonings, it is not the first-line treatment for TCA overdose and is generally reserved for severe cases.

 

Option C. Administer fomepizole: This is used for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not for TCA overdose.

 

Option D. Administer flumazenil: This is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose and is not useful in cases of TCA overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium bicarbonate is crucial for managing TCA overdose due to its ability to quickly mitigate the cardiotoxic effects associated with this type of poisoning, emphasizing the importance of rapid and appropriate intervention in such emergencies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to a hospital with focal seizures. His renal function was normal. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbamazepine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Carbamazepine (DOC) and oxcarbazepine (related drug), phenytoin, lamotrigine and levetiracetam are currently the first line drugs approved for the initial treatment of focal seizures, including those that secondarily generalize. Overall, they have very similar efficacy, but differences in pharmacokinetics and toxicity are the main determinants for use in each patient.
  • An advantage of carbamazepine is that its metabolism follows first-order pharmacokinetics, and the relationship between drug dose, serum levels, and toxicity is linear.
  • Oxcarbazepine has the advantage of lesser enzyme induction (and thus drug interactions) than carbamazepine. However, it has more association with dilutional hyponatremia than carbamazepine.
  • Lamotrigine tends to be well-tolerated in terms of side effects. However, patients need to be particularly vigilant about the possibility of a skin rash during the initiation of therapy. This can be extremely severe and lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome if unrecognized and if the medication is not discontinued immediately.
  • Valproic acid is an effective alternative for some patients with partial seizures, especially when the seizures secondarily generalize.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric neurology clinic by concerned parents due to episodes characterized by sudden bending forward of the body with stiffening of the arms and legs. The episodes last for a few seconds and occur in clusters. After thorough evaluation, the child is diagnosed with infantile spasms. Considering the need for effective treatment to prevent potential developmental delays associated with this condition, which of the following is the drug of choice for managing infantile spasms in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACTH

 

Option C:

 

ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone) is considered one of the drugs of choice for the treatment of infantile spasms, a severe form of epilepsy in infants. ACTH has been shown to be effective in reducing and often stopping the spasms, thereby improving the developmental outcome for many children. Its use is based on its ability to modulate the adrenal axis and reduce the frequency of spasms, although the exact mechanism in infantile spasms is not fully understood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Valproate: While valproate is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic drug used for various seizure types, it is not the first-line treatment for infantile spasms.

 

Option B. Ethosuximide: Ethosuximide is used primarily for absence seizures and is not effective for infantile spasms.

 

Option D. Vigabatrin: Vigabatrin is an alternative first-line treatment for infantile spasms, especially in cases associated with tuberous sclerosis. However, ACTH is generally considered the drug of choice, particularly in spasms of unknown cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize ACTH as a first-line treatment option for infantile spasms.

questions.text: About anti-epileptic drugs, which of the following is an incorrect match?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absence seizures - Phenytoin 

 

Option C: 

 

Phenytoin and carbamazepine worsen absence and myoclonic seizure. Drug of choice for absence seizure is ethosuximide.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. GTCS (Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures) - Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is considered one of the first-line treatments for generalized tonic-clonic seizures, making this a correct match.

 

Option B. Focal- Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is one of the fist line drugs for focal seizures making this a correct match.

 

Option D. Myoclonic seizures - Valproate: Valproate is a first-line treatment for myoclonic seizures, which are characterized by sudden, brief muscle jerks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to understand the first-line antiepileptic drug choices for different types of seizures: phenytoin and carbamazepine are not used in absence seizure however they even worsen absence and myoclonic seizure.

choices.text: Anxiolytic + Muscle relaxant
Used as sedative hypnotic
Used as Muscle relaxant

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding properties of Buspirone?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anxiolytic alone

 

Option B:

 

Buspirone is primarily known for its anxiolytic properties without the muscle relaxant, sedative, or anticonvulsant effects typical of benzodiazepines. It acts as a partial agonist at serotonin 5-HT1A receptors and possibly affects dopamine receptors, which contributes to its anxiolytic effect. Its mechanism of action is distinct from that of benzodiazepines, and it does not exhibit the same dependency potential or cause significant sedation, making it a preferred option for long-term management of anxiety in certain patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anxiolytic + Muscle relaxant: This is incorrect because buspirone does not have muscle relaxant properties.
 

Option C. Used as sedative hypnotic: This is incorrect as buspirone does not have sedative properties typical of sedative-hypnotics like benzodiazepines and is not used to induce sleep.
 

Option D. Used as Muscle relaxant: This is incorrect because buspirone is not used as a muscle relaxant; its primary use is for anxiety without the sedative and muscle relaxant effects associated with other anxiolytics.
 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize buspirone as an anxiolytic medication that is used for its anti-anxiety effects without causing significant sedation, muscle relaxation, or the dependency issues associated with benzodiazepines.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is commonly used to promote abstinence in patients with alcohol use disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acamprosate.

 

 Acamprosate is a medication that is used to promote abstinence in patients with alcohol use disorder. It works by modulating the levels of neurotransmitters in the brain that are involved in alcohol dependence and craving.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option B. Bupropion is a medication that is used to treat depression and smoking cessation, but it has not been shown to be effective for alcohol use disorder.
  • Option C. Methadone is an opioid agonist medication that is primarily used to treat opioid addiction by reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings.
  • Option D. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that is used to treat acute opioid poisoning.

choices.text: Phenothiazines reduces its anti-Parkinsonian efficacy.
It is a pro-drug.
Pyridoxine reduces the effect of levodopa in Parkinsonism.
Domperidone blocks levodopa induced emesis as well as its therapeutic potential.

questions.text: All the following statements regarding levodopa are correct except.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Domperidone blocks levodopa induced emesis and its therapeutic potential.

 

Option D:

 

Domperidone is effectively used to manage the side effects of nausea and vomiting associated with levodopa treatment in Parkinson's disease, without affecting the drug’s therapeutic benefits. This is because domperidone, a peripheral dopamine antagonist, does not cross the blood-brain barrier and hence does not affect the central dopaminergic activity crucial for levodopa's effectiveness. It acts outside the brain in areas accessible to blood circulation, such as the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), which can access the circulatory system.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenothiazines: can indeed reduce levodopa's effectiveness by blocking dopamine receptors.

 

Option B.  Levodopa is a pro-drug, converted to dopamine in the brain to exert its effects.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) increases the peripheral metabolism of levodopa, reducing its availability to cross into the brain and therefore diminishing its effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Domperidone is used to reduce levodopa-induced nausea without impairing its anti-Parkinsonian actions, demonstrating its value in managing side effects while preserving the main therapeutic intent of Parkinson’s disease treatment.

choices.text: NA+ 5HT reuptake inhibitor
Predominantly NA reuptake inhibitor

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with symptoms of depression. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of nortriptyline, a medication that can be used to treat his depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Predominantly NA reuptake inhibitor

 

Explanation:

 

Most of the TCAs act by inhibiting the reuptake of both 5-HT and NA but nortriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that works by blocking the reuptake of mainly norepinephrine (NA) in the brain. This leads to increased levels of this neurotransmitter in the synapse, which can help to alleviate symptoms of depression. Other selective NRIs include Reboxetine, atomoxetine etc. 

EXPLANATION OF OTHER OPTIONS 

  • Option A. SNRI: Refers to serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, which are a newer class of antidepressant medications that work by blocking the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. Examples include venlafaxine, duloxetine and milnacipran.
  • Option B. SSRI: Refers to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, which are another class of newer antidepressant medications that work by blocking the reuptake of serotonin. These include fluoxetine, citalopram like drugs. 
  • Option C. NA+ 5HT reuptake inhibitor: It is not a specific class of antidepressant medication but may refer to medications that block the reuptake of both norepinephrine and serotonin like SNRI.

Educational Objective:

Nortriptyline is a TCA that acts predominatly as NA reuptake inhibitor unlike other TCAs which inhibit reuptake of both serotonin and nor-adrenaline.

choices.text: All the above

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the management of tardive dyskinesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valbenazine.

 

Option C:

 

Valbenazine is specifically approved for the treatment of tardive dyskinesia (TD), a condition characterized by involuntary, repetitive movements of the face and tongue, often developing after prolonged use of typical antipsychotic drugs. The efficacy of valbenazine in managing TD is due to its role as a vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2) inhibitor, which modulates dopamine release and reduces the symptoms associated with this disorder. Its mechanism focuses on addressing the dopamine receptor supersensitivity that develops due to chronic dopamine D2 receptor blockade by antipsychotics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Benzhexol: Also known as trihexyphenidyl, is an anticholinergic drug, which is contraindicated in the management of TD as it can potentially worsen the symptoms.

 

Option B. Promethazine: Has anticholinergic properties and is also contraindicated in TD for similar reasons to benzhexol, as it may exacerbate the involuntary movements.

Option D. All the above: Incorrect because both benzhexol and promethazine are not suitable for the management of TD and are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valbenazine is specifically used for the management of tardive dyskinesia due to its VMAT2 inhibitory action, unlike anticholinergic drugs such as benzhexol and promethazine, which are contraindicated in this condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of alcohol use disorder presents to your clinic for treatment. He has a long history of heavy drinking and has recently stopped drinking. Which of the following medications is commonly used to prevent relapse in patients with alcohol use disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naltrexone.

 

Option B:

 

  • Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist medication that is used to treat alcohol use disorder by reducing the craving for alcohol and preventing relapse in individuals who have stopped drinking. It works by blocking the effects of endorphins, which are naturally occurring chemicals in the brain that are released in response to alcohol consumption.
  • Methadone is an opioid agonist medication that is primarily used to treat opioid addiction by reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings.
  • Naloxone and nalmefene are also opioid antagonist medications, but they are primarily used to reverse opioid overdose and are not typically used in the treatment of alcohol use disorder.
